content.title: Welcome to the Obojobo Visual Editor

text.value: Welcome to the Obojobo Visual Editor

This Visual Editor Tutorial is an editable guide to creating Obojobo modules. By following along and trying the edits yourself, you will learn how to leverage all the features in Obojobo you need to build your own modules. We invite you to open this module and edit as you go!
Saving

First is the most important thing; how and when to save your changes. While editing your module, your changes are only temporarily saved in this browser tab. To be clear, if you close this tab without saving, those changes will be lost.
Saved changes will be shown to the next students who start your module. To avoid this, you may prefer to duplicate your module and make edits to the copy.
To save, click File > Save from the tool bar menu or press ctrl+s.
Navigation

The navigation panel along the left side list all the pages and assessments that make up your module. Pages are identified by the larger circle ◯ symbol, and assessments are identified by the Ⓠ symbol.  You can have as many pages as you wish, but only one assessment per module.
Clicking an item in the navigation menu displays its contents on the right - the area this paragraph is in right now. Navigating to other pages while editing will not erase your changes.
Adding Pages

When a page is selected in the Navigation menu, a +Page button will appear below it.  Clicking this button will create a new page below the current  page.  Similarly, if all pages or assessments are deleted, a +Add Page or +Add Assessment button will appear, allowing you to create a new page or assessment.
Detail Menus

The circle with three dots next to any item opens a details menu with more information and options.  Sometimes you need to select that item for the details menu icon to appear. These menus are how you access the id and triggers associated with each part of your module.  In addition, each details menu can contain specialized options pertaining to the content it's controlling.
For instance, the details menu at the top of the navigation title allows you to edit the module title and start page.

The details menus for pages and assessments allow you to edit their titles, delete, duplicate, and change their order.  Similarly, the circles next to each chunk (paragraphs, images, etc.) inside a page allow you to edit that chunk's id and triggers.
A Special Note About ID's

When changing any item's id, make sure to use a unique value.  Duplicate ids are not allowed in a module, and the menu will not close if the id you are trying to use already exists elsewhere in the module.
Toolbars
The toolbars at the top of the page provide additional actions. These toolbars are always visible at the top of the page, no matter how far down you scroll.
File Toolbar

The file toolbar sits just below the module name, and contains a series of menus that provide additional functionality to the Obojobo Visual Editor. Many of these functions can also be accessed with shortcut keys.

Inside the file toolbar, the File menu allows you to Save the current changes to the menu (CTRL+S), open up a new Obojobo module, or make a copy of the current module.  It also allows you to download the module as either an XML or a JSON document.  You can also Delete the module from this menu or copy the LTI link to add into your LMS course.

After the File menu is the Edit menu, which provides access to some typical editor commands.  You can undo (CTRL+Z) or redo (CTRL+Y) any changes that you have made, or delete content.  You can also select all the content within a single page (CTRL+A)

The View menu can also be found in the file toolbar.  It allows you to change the way you are editing the module, swapping over to the XML editor or the JSON editor in order to manually edit the module.  It also allows you to preview the module as the students would see it.
The Insert menu follows the View menu and allows you to insert different kinds of content into the document.  All content types are inserted with blank text and default values, ready to be edited!

Finally, the Format menu allows you to make formatting changes to the content within a page. The Text submenu allows you change the inline style of any text, including making it bold or italicized. The Paragraph Styles submenu allows you to change the type of the currently selected content, swapping between Text, Headings, and Code.  Only those three types of content can be swapped, so selecting other types of content and then changing their Paragraph Style will have no effect.  The last submenu, Align & Indent, allows you to change the indent style of a block of text, or to swap how it is aligned on the page.
Content Toolbar

Much like the Format menu in the file toolbar, the content toolbar provides buttons that can change the formatting of the content within a page.  Each button also has a keyboard shortcut associated with it, to allow for uninterrupted typing.  For more information about the Content Toolbar, see the Text Editing page.
Adding Content
Within the pages of an Obojobo Module, you can add any of the supported Obojobo nodes. Nodes range from simple Text and Headings to more complex items such as Questions.

When you click on an existing node, two + buttons will appear above and below the node. Hovering over either of these buttons will open up a menu that lists all nodes that can be inserted. Clicking on any of the buttons will insert a new node into the document, either above or below the existing node.
Text Editing
The most basic component of the Obojobo Visual Editor is the text node. Text nodes allow you to insert the main content of your Modules in paragraph form.
An empty text node displays a prompt for you to enter some text so that you don't lose track of where you can type.
Each text node consists of a series of one or more text lines.
Hitting the Enter key within a text node will make a new text line, which will sit just below the previous line.
Try it! Hit the Enter key after this text to make a new line.
Hitting the Enter key twice or hitting the Enter key on an empty line will create a new text node. A new text node is like a new paragraph and is separated from the previous text node by extra space.
Try it! Hit the Enter key twice after this line to make a new text node.
Align

Text lines can be left aligned, right aligned, or center aligned.  The alignment applies to each individual line, so a text node can have multiple alignments within it.  For example, this line is left aligned,
this line is right aligned,
and this line is centered.
The alignment can be changed by using the buttons in the toolbar, or by pressing CTRL+Shift+L for left align, CTRL+Shift+R for right align, or CTRL+Shift+E for center align.
Indentation
Text lines can also be indented. An indention applies only to a single text line, but the line will maintain the indent even when the text wraps around, as seen here.
Text Lines can also contain multiple indents, up to a maximum of 20 levels of indentation
Indents can be applied by pressing Alt+Tab, and they can be removed by pressing Shift+Tab. You can also use the indent and un-indent buttons in the toolbar.
Try it! Use the Alt+Tab and Shift+Tab keys, or the toolbar buttons, to change the indent level in this line of text.

Text nodes can also have a hanging indent, where the first part a wrapping text line sticks out further to the left than subsequent lines.  Hanging indents can be toggled by pressing CTRL+H, or by using the hanging indent button in the toolbar.
Try it!  Use the CTRL+H keys, or the toolbar buttons, to toggle a hanging indent on this line of text.
Whitespace
Text lines can contain whitespace such as Tabs anywhere within the line, including the beginning and the end.
Adding a Tab at the beginning of a line does not affect the indentation even if the line wraps around.
Paragraph Styles

At times, you may insert a text node and then realize you want it to be a different kind of node.  In that case, the drop-down menu in the toolbar will allow you to change the paragraph style to a heading or to a code style.  You can also use the menu to change code and headings back into text.
Text Styling
Text can also be styled. To apply styles, highlight some text and use the toolbar at the top of the page or the shortcut keys.
Style Shortcuts
Style
Shortcut
Bold Text
Ctrl+B or ⌘+B
Italic Text
Ctrl+I or ⌘+I
Strikethrough Text
Ctrl+D or ⌘+D
Quoted Text
Ctrl+" or ⌘+"
Monospaced Text
Ctrl+M or ⌘+M
Inline Latex Math
Ctrl+/ or ⌘+/
Link
Ctrl+K or ⌘+K
Colored Text
Ctrl+Shift+P or ⌘+Shift+P
Superscript
Ctrl+. or ⌘+.
Subscript
Ctrl+, or ⌘+,
Headings
In addition to text nodes, you can also insert Heading nodes. These can be used to separate sections or to designate quick links.
Headings can have one of 6 different levels. To toggle the heading level, click on the dropdown menu in the toolbar select the new heading style.
Level One Heading

Level one headings are usually used only once on a page, as the title of the whole page. If they are not the first node on the page, they will show up as links in the navigation bar when a student views an Obojobo module.
Level Two Heading
Level two headings usually denote the major subsections of a page. They also show up as links in the navigation bar when a student views an Obojobo module.
Level Three Heading
Level Four Heading
Level Five Heading
Level Six Heading
Level three, four, five, and six headings usually denote subcategories within each subsection. These do not show up as links in the navigation bar.
Lists
Lists nodes allow for concise organization of data, in either numbered (ordered) or bullet-point (unordered) format.
You can swap between ordered and unordered lists by pressing the swap button below the list, which appears when the list is selected.
Bullet-Point List (Unordered)
One Item
Another Item
A Third Item
Numbered List (Ordered)
The First Item
The Second Item
The Third Item
List Levels

Lists can contain any number of levels. The level can be increased by pressing Tab at the start of the list item (or ALT+Tab anywhere in the list) or decreased by pressing Shift+Tab. You can also use the indent and un-indent buttons in the toolbar to change the level.
Try it! Use Tab and Shift+Tab, or the toolbar buttons, to increase and decrease the levels of this list.
List Level 1
List Level 2
List Level 3
List Level
List Level 5
Back to Level 4
Back to Level 1
Tables
A Table node allows for a concise display of complex data sets. Tables can have an unlimited number of rows and columns, although a large number of columns may become unwieldy.
Cell Insertion and Deletion

When a table is inserted, it only has a single cell. To add more rows and columns, click on a cell in the table, and then click on the arrow in the top right corner of that cell.  A menu will appear with table options, allowing you to add rows above or below the current cell, and columns to the left or right of the current cell.
Try it! Use the menu to add a few rows and columns to this table.
Single Cell Table
Once a table has a few rows and columns, you can use the Delete Row or Delete Column option in the same dropdown menu to remove rows and columns
Deleting the last row or column in the table will delete the entire table.
Try it! Use the menu to delete a few rows and columns from this table.
Header 1
Header 2
Header 3
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Item 4
Item 5
Item 6
Header Rows
The header row for a table can also be toggled on or off. Use the Toggle Header button to turn the header on and off.
Accessibility Warning! Tables without headers can be very hard for text-to-speech devices to decipher. Try to use headers whenever possible.
For more information on table accessibility, read the WebAIM article about table accessibility. (Right-click to follow link)
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Item 4
Item 5
Item 6
Item 7
Item 8
Item 9
Automatic Width Cells
When tables are inserted, their cells have fixed width.

To make the width of table cells flexible relative to cell contents, click on one of the cells and use the Switch to auto width cells button. To make cells have fixed width back again, click on one of the cells and use the Switch to fixed width cells button.
Course Name
Professor
United States History: 1492-1877 (3 Credit Hours)
Dr. Doe
Breaks
A Break node provides a logical and visual division on the page.
Break nodes can have one of two different widths: normal and large. To toggle in-between the two widths, click on the break and then use the Toggle Size button to alter the size.
Try it! Toggle the size of this Break.
Figures
Figure nodes allow you to display images within the Obojobo Module.
Figure Properties

When a Figure is inserted, it has no display image, and all of its properties are set to default values. To change these properties, click on the Figure and then click the Image Properties button; this will open up an Image Properties dialog. Inside the dialog, clicking Cancel will close the dialog without changing any of the properties of the Figure, and clicking OK will close the dialog and change the properties of the Figure.
Try it! Click on this Figure, then open and close the Image Properties dialog.
URL

When the properties box is first opened, it will ask you to upload a new image, or enter the URL of an image that has already been uploaded to the internet. It will also show you a list of your recently uploaded images, and you can select any of them to upload into the module.
Try it! Change the image in the following figure by opening the Image Properties dialog, pasting in an image URL or uploading an image, and then clicking OK
Alt Text

Once an image has been selected, other properties will be displayed in the Image Properties dialog.  The first of these is the alt text. The alt text will not be seen by most users, but it is displayed when the image does not load or when assistive technology such as text-to-speech devices are used. Therefore, even though it is not required, adding alt text makes your Obojobo module more accessible. Images without alt text will display a warning above them, so it is easy to see which images still need alt text.
Try it! Add alt text to the following figure by opening the Image Properties dialog, typing into the Alt Text input, and then clicking OK.
For more information on writing alt text, read the WebAIM article about alt text and accessibility. (Right-click on the link to open it)
Caption Width

The second property that can be set is the caption width. Captions can either be restricted to the same width as the image, or allowed to extend beyond the image's width. Restricting the width can provide some visual consistency to the page, however longer captions can sometimes have a negative impact on the page's structure if their width is restricted to a smaller image. Note that the caption width option only applies for small or custom sized figures. For medium and large sizes the image is already as wide as the page (or wider).
This caption is restricted to the width of the image, so it can only use the same amount of space on the page as the image does.

This caption is allowed to extend beyond the width of the image, so it is able to fill the same amount of space on the page as a regular text node. It is quite long, and might harm the layout of the page if its width was restricted as it would take up a fair amount of vertical space. This may prevent other parts of the document, or even the image itself, from being viewed at the same time if it is too long and the image is not very wide.
Try it! Use the Image Properties dialog to change the caption width for the above images to see how it changes the way they are displayed.
Figure Sizes
The third property in the Image Properties dialog is the image size. Figures can be displayed in several different sizes: small, medium, large, and custom.
A small image
The same image, in a medium size
The same image, in a large size

Figures that have a custom size have a height and width property. The best practice for custom image sizes is to assign either a custom width or a custom height, but not both. A Figure with either a custom width or a custom height will be scaled appropriately, but a Figure with both a custom width and a custom height will be squished or stretched to fit the custom size.
An image with a custom width
An image with a custom height
An image with a custom width and height
Try it! Use the Image Properties dialog to change the size of any of the above images.
Captions
Every Figure has a caption that sits below the image. This caption is optional, but can provide more information about the image.  You can edit the caption by clicking directly beneath any image.
The caption could contain a detailed image description, attribution information, or further context
Excerpts

Excerpts provide a way to visually distinguish certain parts of your content from others, and offer a variety of visual styles to do so. Excerpts can contain most other node types and can optionally be given a citation, and all of the presets can be further customized.
Presets
Excerpts come with a number of presets for convenience, any of which can be additionally customized. Below are just a few examples:
Simple Filled
Historical
Receipt
Hacker Green
Customizing

All presets can be further customized in a number of ways. The top and bottom borders of most excerpts can be changed depending on the selected excerpt type, and all aspects of an excerpt can be controlled in the Advanced options... menu visible when an excerpt is selected.
Try it! Click into the excerpt node below and click the Advanced options... button to see more ways you can customize it. Each option that can be customized will be further explained below.
Customize me!
Style
The style of an excerpt determines its basic appearance, options broken down into several categories:
Simple: Basic excerpt options, boxes with either a simple background color, simple border, or drop shadow.
Paper: Various paper-like backgrounds in different colors, with an optional paper-like texture effect.

Computer: Excerpts themed to look like a terminal input or a CRT monitor screen in several colors, with scan lines and an optional glowing effect. Themed appearances based on classic operating systems or web browsers can also be selected.
Callout: Several options for callout boxes with static header text and an icon on the lefthand side.
Font
Several web-safe font choices are available for use in any excerpt style and can be freely selected regardless of the chosen style.
Effect

Depending on the style of the excerpt, and in some cases even the specific type of excerpt, an optional effect may be applied. This effect may be a drop shadow, a paper-like texture, or a text glow depending on the selected excerpt style.
Width
An excerpt can be configured to take 100%, 75%, 50% or 25% of the available width in a document.
Font Size
All text within an excerpt will be scaled up or down based on the selected option: smaller, normal, or larger.
Line Height
The amount of padding around each line of text in an excerpt will be added based on the selected option: less, standard, or more.
Examples
Quoting a literary work:

content.citation: Excerpt from Dune, by Frank Herbert

text.value: I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration. I will face my fear. I will permit it to pass over me and through me. And when it has gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain.
Visually distinguishing an idea:
Saying that a thing is like another thing, is a simile, but saying that a thing is a different thing is a metaphor.
Prompting with a practice problem:
Find the solution for the following equation where a = 4, b = 5, and c = 6
Just for fun:
Some Store
1 Unsalted Butter........1.00
Math Equations
Math Equations allow for the display of complex math equations on their own line.
LaTeX Formatting
Math Equations use LaTeX to represent equations. For more information on LaTeX equations, here are a couple of helpful LaTeX tutorials. (Right-click on the links to follow them)
Basic LaTeX Math Tutorial
Common Math Symbols in LaTeX
LaTeX Greek Alphabet
Inline Math Equations

Math Equations can be displayed inline with any text. To use inline Math Equations, type the LaTeX representation of the Math Equation, highlight the LaTeX, and then either click the LaTeX button in the toolbar or use the LaTeX shortcut (CTRL+/). The highlighted text will then have a light blue background, and will render as a Math Equation in the Obojobo Viewer
Here is an example of an inline equation: \theta
This equation will render as a θ in the viewer. Open this module in a preview to see it rendered properly.
Building Math Equations

To change a math equation, click on the Math Equation. An edit button will appear, and clicking the button will open a dialog with four input fields. Type the LaTeX representation of the equation into the Latex field, and then click OK. The Math Equation will be updated, and will display next to the edit button.
Try it! Click on the empty Math Equation chunk below, open the edit box, and enter y=mx+b into the input box labeled "Latex".
If the LaTeX equation is mis-typed, an error message will appear. Fix the following Math Equation by correcting the spelling of thata to theta.

A Math Equation can also have a label. To change the label, type into the Optional Label input in the dialog.  The label will be displayed below the equation, and can provide an easy shorthand to refer to the equation in the rest of your content.

Because text-to-speech devices do not always read the LaTeX out correctly, there is the option to provide an alt text for the equation.  When providing alt text for an equation, be sure the the words are unambiguous, and provide all necessary context such as parenthesis and grouping.  For advice on writing out accessible Math Equations, use the MathSpeak standards.
To add alt text to the math equation, type it into the Alt Text input.

content.alt: y equals m times x plus b

text.value: You can also alter the size of your Math Equations by changing the value in the Size field.  The size value is a multiplier, so a value of 1.5 makes the equation 1.5x as large as usual.
Math Equation chunks can also be aligned to the left or right. Here's a few examples
Action Buttons
The Action Button node executes a series of predefined actions when clicked. This is useful for guiding student navigation.
By default, an Action Button appears in its collapsed state, with only the label visible. Clicking on the button will display the buttons actions, and allow the label to be edited.
Try It! Change the label on this button.
A Basic Label
Action Button Actions
Clicking on a button also displays its list of actions, and a button to add a new actions. Clicking on a different node will hide the actions again.
An Action Button with Two Actions

To add an action to an Action Button, click the Edit Triggers button. A dialog will appear; make sure the button has a When "The student clicks the button" trigger, click Add Action, and then select the desired action name from the dropdown menu and fill out any value that is needed for that action (see Action Details) before clicking the Save button. The Obojobo Visual Editor will validate the value, and then save the action into the Action Button if the value was valid. If the value was not valid, it will display an error message.
To remove an action from an Action Button, click Edit Triggers and then click the X button in the upper righthand corner of the action. This will delete both the action and its associated value.

Try it! Add and remove a few actions from the button below (nav:prev, nav:next, nav:lock, nav:unlock, nav:open, nav:close, and nav:toggle are the easiest ones to try since they do not require a value)
Action Manipulation Button
Action Details

The Action Button supports a wide array of actions, some of which require an additional value in order to function properly. For a comprehensive list of actions and what they do, read the Obojobo Action documentation. (right-click to follow link)
Code
A Code node displays code fragments in a recognizable format.
// Sample code
function main() {
print("Hello world");

Code nodes function similarly to text nodes. A single Code node can contain multiple lines, including empty lines. Code nodes can contain as many empty lines as needed. Unlike Text nodes, two consecutive blank lines within a single Code node will not be turned into a new Code node.  Code nodes can also be converted into text or headings by selecting the node and using the drop-down menu in the toolbar.
YouTube
YouTube nodes allow you to display YouTube videos inside of your Obojobo Module.

To change the source of the video, find the URL or YouTube id of the video that you wish to embed, and then click the Edit button in the upper right-hand corner of the video. A dialog will open; paste the URL or YouTube id (which will be automatically converted into a URL) into the input in the dialog.

If you only want your students to watch a specific section of the video, you can click the "Set Start & End Time..." button and enter a start time (in seconds or MM:SS format) and an end time (in seconds or MM:SS format) in the dialog.  When students press play, the video will begin at the specified start time, and play until the specified end time, ensuring that the students see only the relevant content.
IFrames
An IFrame node displays external web content within an Obojobo module.
Warning! IFrames present unique challenges based on the security settings and the size of the embedded site. Make sure to test all IFrames in the student view to validate that they load as expected.
IFrame Properties

When an IFrame is inserted, it has no source, and all of its properties are set to default values. To change these properties, click on the IFrame Properties button; this will open up an IFrame Properties dialog. Inside the dialog, clicking Cancel will close the dialog without changing any of the properties of the IFrame, and clicking OK will close the dialog and change the properties of the IFrame.
Try it! Click on this IFrame, then open and close the IFrame Properties dialog.
Title and Source

The source of the IFrame is the URL of the content the you wish to embed. The title of the IFrame is the name that will be displayed to students before the IFrame is loaded. If an IFrame does not have a title, the source URL will be displayed instead.
An IFrame with a source and a title:
An IFrame with only a source:
To change the source or the title of an IFrame, open the IFrame Properties dialog, and then type into the appropriate input boxes.
Try it! Change the source or title of either of the above IFrames.
Options
All IFrames have options that determine how they are displayed. None of these options are required; they simply alter the IFrame from its default display.
Sizing: How the IFrame will be scaled within the window.
Fixed: Size will remain constant for any window size.
Text Width: IFrame will scale to be the same width as text.
Max Width: IFrame will scale to fill the full width of the document.
Dimensions: Set the width and height that the IFrame will be displayed at.
Border: Toggles a border around the edges of the IFrame. This helps to distinguish the IFrame content from the rest of the Obojobo document.

Autoload: Determines whether the IFrame content will be loaded as soon as the student clicks on the page. Be careful when using autoloading, as autoloading IFrames with a large amount of content can cause noticeable lag in loading times.
Fit: How content will be scaled within the IFrame.
Scale: Size of content inside the IFrame will scale up and down to fit (much like scaling an image).
Scroll: Content within the frame remains at its original size. When too large to fit, the contents will scroll instead of scale down.

Initial Zoom: Sets a scale multiplier for the IFrame content. A value of 1 keeps the content at its default size, decimal values such as 0.5 will make the content smaller, and values greater than 1 will make the content larger.
Try it! Open the IFrame Properties dialog and change some of the display option on the following IFrame, then save the document and see how those changes affect the student view.
Controls

The IFrame controls allow the student to manipulate the content of the IFrame once it is loaded. You can toggle these controls on or off; students will only be able to see and use controls that are toggled on.
The reload control reloads the content of the IFrame, much like the refresh page button on a browser.
The new window control opens the content of the IFrame in a new window.
The zoom control allows students to zoom in and out on the content of the IFrame.
Try it! Open the IFrame Properties dialog, and toggle the controls of the following IFrame.
Questions

Questions allow you to gauge the student's comprehension of your material. Questions can be placed directly into a page as practice for the student, or they can be added to a Question Bank in the assessment.
A question contains three basic parts: the content, the multiple choice, and the solution.
Question Content
The content appears at the start of the question and usually describes the question that the student is answering. It can contain any node except for other Questions and Question Banks.
This Question contains both a Heading node and a Text node in its content.
A Simple Question
How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?
An answer
Multiple-Choice Questions

The multiple choice section allows you to create multiple answers for a student, and select which one(s) are correct. Just like the content, a multiple choice answer can hold any node type except for Questions and Question Banks.

By default, each question has one incorrect answer. To add more, click the Add Choice button below the current choices. To delete a choice, click the X button in the upper right-hand corner of the choice.
Try it! Add and delete a few choices in the following Question. (Make sure you click the X inside of a choice to delete it; the X above the question will delete the whole question)
This question has three answer choices: one correct and two incorrect
An incorrect answer choice
A correct answer choice
Another incorrect answer choice
To toggle which choices are correct, simply click on the red Incorrect button or green Correct button on the left side of the choice. A question can have as many correct choices as you would like.
Try it! Toggle the correctness of the answer choices in the following question by clicking on the green buttons.
This question has three correct answers, and no incorrect answers.
A correct answer choice
Another correct answer choice
A third correct answer choice

Choices can also have feedback, which provides more information to the student if they select that choice. The feedback be displayed below the choice once the student hits submit (or during a review if the question is in the assessment), so it is a good place to let the student know where they went wrong, or to provide elaboration on a correct answer.
To add feedback to a choice, click the Add Feedback button. To remove feedback from a choice, simply click the X button in the upper right-hand corner of the feedback.

Try it! Add and remove feedback from any of the answer choices in the following Question. (Make sure you click the X inside of the feedback to delete it; the X above the question will delete the whole question, and the X inside of the choice will delete the choice)
This question has feedback on the incorrect answer, but not the correct one.
This is a correct answer
This is an incorrect answer
Here is some detailed information about the incorrect answer
The feedback can contain any of the same nodes as the content and the choices.
Multiple-Choice Settings
Multiple-Choice questions can have one of two response types: pick one correct answer or pick all correct answers. To change the response type, use the dropdown above the answer choices.

Pick one correct answer questions allow the student to pick a single choice as their answer. If there is more than one correct choice, the student can select any of the correct choices to get the points for that question.
This is a pick-one question with multiple correct answers. The student can only select one answer, and the question will be marked correct if they choose any of the correct choices.
A correct answer
An incorrect answer
Another correct answer
Pick all correct answers questions allow a student to select as many answers as they want. By default, a student must select all the correct choices to get the points for that question.
Alternatively, Partial Scoring can be turned on which allows students to receive partial credit for the question based on how many correct and incorrect choices they select.

In the question below, selecting only one correct answer would result in a 50%, and selecting one correct answer along with the incorrect answer would result in a 0%. Selecting all three answer choices would result in a 50% as well, as the incorrect choice cancels out one of the correct choices.
This is a pick-all question; the student will get it incorrect if they pick any of the wrong answers, or if they fail to pick any of the correct answers.
If Partial Scoring is enabled, then the student can receive partial credit even if they didn't get it completely correct.
The student must pick this answer to get the question correct
The student must not pick this answer to get the question correct
The student must also pick this answer to get the question correct

Questions can also be shuffled or un-shuffled. Shuffled questions will randomize the order of their choices, and un-shuffled questions will retain the order of their choices. By default, questions are shuffled, but this can be turned off by clicking on the toggle-button next to the response type.
The answer choices for the question will appear in the exact order they are displayed
A part of the correct answer
Another part of the correct answer
All of the above
Input-a-number Questions

"Input-a-number" questions require students to input a numeric response. You can define one or more correct answer choices (as well as any number of incorrect answer choices if you want to provide feedback opportunities for common incorrect responses).

By default, each question has one correct answer. To add more, click the + Add possible answer button below the current choices. To delete a choice, click the X button in the upper right-hand corner of the choice.
Try it! Add and delete a few choices in the following Question. (Make sure you click the X inside of a choice to delete it; the X above the question will delete the whole question)
What is 2 + 2 = ?
Units
You can make your questions more specific by specifying the units that the answer is expected in by using the Units Text box.
Try it! Preview this module and see how the answer input for this question shows the text "grams" after the input box.
How many grams are in 1 kilogram?
grams
Other numeric types

In addition to decimal values you can also define possible answer choices in scientific notation, fractional values, hexadecimal values, octal values or binary values. The table below shows some examples of the different types of number formats allowed:
Number Type
Valid syntax examples
Decimal
Scientific Notation
Fractional
Hexadecimal
Octal
Binary
Try it! Preview this question and try some of the possible answer inputs. Then, try adding your own answer choices using some of the other syntaxes.
Here are valid responses to this example question:
0xF90F
Answer equivalency

Student responses are accepted if they are of equivalent values. For example, if an answer choice is 1.23e4 then both 1.23e4, 12.3e3 (improper form) and 12300 are all accepted as the same response. In addition, decimal values with enough precision will be accepted for fractional values (and visa versa). For example, the answer 0.333333 will be accepted for the answer choice 1/3, and likewise the answer 2/3 will be accepted for the answer choice 0.666666.
Try it! Preview this question and try inputting various equivalent values.
Here are the answer choices for this question:
Try also answering 0.333333 and 2/6 instead of 1/3, and 2/3 and 200/300 instead of 0.666666.
Percent and absolute error
For questions where you expect to give students some leeway, such as scientific or physics questions, you'll want to provide some margin of error.

Try it! The question below allows for a 1 percent error. Try expanding this to allow for a 5 percent error, then preview this question to experiment with answering the question to see what is and isn't accepted as a correct response. Finally, try changing the Error Type to Absolute, and experiment with accepted responses. With an answer of 0.679 and an absolute error of 5 any value from -4.321 to 5.679 will be accepted.
What is the molarity of 0.4444 mol of CoCl_2 in 0.654 L of solution?
M
Ranges
You can also more directly provide a range of accepted values by choosing the Range answer type.
Try it! Experiment with the start and end values of the answer choice below, then preview this question to try various answers.
To answer this question correctly, input any number from -100 to 100.
Question Solution

The solution will display after the question has been answered. In practice questions, it is accessible after every time that the student hits submit. In the assessment, it is accessible during a full review. It will be displayed regardless of which choices the student selected, so it is a good place to put general post-question information.

To add a solution to the question, click the Add Solution button at the bottom of the question. To delete a solution, click the X button in the top right corner of the solution. The solution can contain any other node, and it can be as long as desired.
The Solution
Some more detail for the student, this can be as long as needed.
This question contains a solution, which will be displayed after submission no matter which choice the student picks
An answer choice
Another answer choice
Survey Questions

Questions can also be marked as Survey Only, which means they will not be graded.  Survey Only questions do not have correct and incorrect answers, and so toggling the Survey Only button to on will remove the Correct and Incorrect buttons from the Question
Try it! Toggle the Survey Only button on the following Question.
A survey question
One survey response
Another survey response
Other Options
Reveal Answer Button

By default Input-a-number questions show a Reveal Answer button when answered incorrectly. This is helpful if a student is unable to come up with any correct answers. Multiple-Choice questions don't have any Reveal Answer buttons since it's easy to find the correct answer if a student is unsure. However, you can override this option for any question and decide when (if at all) you want to show this button.

Try it! Change the question below so that the Reveal Answer button is shown even before a student responds to it. Here's how: Click inside the question to focus on it, then click on the (...) menu that appears in the upper right just outside the question. Next, find the Allow Reveal Answer? option and change it to Yes. Save your module and then preview this question and notice how the Reveal Answer button shows up, allowing students to reveal the answer without having to guess first.
What is 2 + 2 = ?
Question Banks

Question Banks allow a set of questions to be displayed together. Mostly, Question Banks are used within Assessments to select and display a certain subset of questions. Within Pages, Question Banks simply display all of their questions one after another.

Question Banks can contain both questions and other Question Banks. To add a Question or a Question Bank, click the Add Question or Add Question Bank button at the bottom of the Question Bank. To delete a Question or a Question Bank, click the X in the top right corner of the item you wish to delete.
A sample question
The correct answer
Importing Questions

Any Question that has been added to the module can be imported into a Question Bank. To import Questions, select anywhere inside the Question Bank and click on the circle with three dots at the top right of the Question Bank to open the details menu. Clicking the Import Questions button within this menu will open a dialog that displays all of the Questions that are in the current module. Inside the dialog, clicking Cancel will close it without importing any Questions, and clicking Import will update the Question Bank to include all of the questions that were selected.
Try it! Import a few Questions into this Question Bank.
Question Banks in Assessments

Inside of an Assessment, a Question Bank selects a few of its children to display. The How many questions should be displayed? property at the top of the Question Bank determines how many items are chosen. If the number displayed is greater than the number of items within the Question Bank, all of the items will be displayed.
A Question Bank also has a How should questions be selected? property, which determines how it picks children to display.
In Order Selection

Question Banks with in order selection will pick items in order. The Question Bank below will choose one question sequentially. This means it'll choose the first question for the first attempt, the second question for the second attempt, and so on. Once all questions have been chosen the selection will start over at the beginning.
This question would be selected the first time
The correct answer
This question would be selected the second time
The correct answer
Random Selection
Question Banks with random selection will pick questions completely randomly. Questions can appear in any order, and may or may not be re-selected across attempts.
This question might be selected the first or the second time, both times, or neither time.
The correct answer
This other question might be selected the first or second time, both times, or neither time.
The correct answer
Random With No Repeats Selection

Question banks with random, no repeats selection pick questions at random but prioritize selecting questions that have not been used in a previous attempt. On a student's first attempt, this is identical to random selection, but successive attempts will pick randomly from questions the student hasn't seen yet.
This question might or might not be selected the first time, and will be selected the second time if it is not selected the first.
The correct answer
This other question might or might not be selected the first time, and will be selected the second time if it is not selected the first.
The correct answer
How did you do?
You have {{assessment:attemptsRemaining}} attempts remaining.
Retry Assessment
Assessment
An assessment works a little differently from a regular page.
Assessment Nodes

The assessment consists of four different sections:  the Launch Page, the Question Bank, the Score Actions, and the Rubric.  It also has some additional settings that can be accessed from the navigation menu
Assessment Settings

Much like a normal page, Assessment settings can be accessed by clicking the circle with three dots that appears next to the Assessment title in the navigation menu.  Assessments have two extra settings that pages do not have: the number of attempts and the review type.

The number of attempts controls how many times the student can take this assessment. Enter a number to limit the number of attempts, or type unlimited to allow the student to try as many times as they want.

The review type describes how answers will be displayed after an attempt has ended.  You can allow students to always see the correct answers, to see the correct answers only after their last attempt, or to never be allowed to see the correct answers.  Even when the student cannot see which answer was the correct one, they will still be able to see which questions they got correct and which they got incorrect.
Launch Page
The second required node is the launch page. This is the page that a student sees the first time they navigate to an assessment.

Somewhere on the launch page, there should be an Action Button that executes the Start an attempt for "assessment-id" action. When clicked, this button will allow the student to start the assessment. Here is an example of the launch button:
Start Assessment
Question Bank
The third required node is the Question Bank. This Question Bank functions the same way as a Question Bank within a page.
Score Actions

The fourth required node is the list of Score Actions. Score Actions are the pages that are displayed at the top of a review after a student has completed an attempt. Different Score Actions can be displayed for different score ranges.

To describe a score range, use square brackets to denote an inclusive range, so that [0,100] would match all scores from 0 to 100, including 0 and 100. Use parenthesis to denote an exclusive range, such that (0, 100) would match all scores between 0 and 100, and would not match 0 or 100. Square brackets and parenthesis can also be mixed and matched, allowing for ranges such as [0,100), which matches all scores except 100, and (0,100], which matches all scores except 0. Any two numbers can be placed between the brackets and parenthesis, and the numbers should be separated by a comma.
In most cases, Score Actions should contain an Action Button that executes the assessment:attemptStart action, just like the Launch Page. This will allow the students to complete multiple attempts.
Rubric
The fifth node in the assessment is a Rubric. The Rubric allows you to set custom parameters about passing and failing scores for the assessment.
When processing the student's score, the assessment first determines their raw score by dividing the number of questions correct by the total number of questions and then multiplying by 100.
((correct / questions) * 100 = raw score)
The Rubric then checks the raw score. If the raw score is greater than or equal to the Passing Score, the rubric declares the student as passed.
If the student takes all of their allowed attempts and does not achieve at least one Passing Score, then the Unable to Pass Result will be sent to the grade book.

The Rubric also allows you to set up to 20 mods that change the student's score. These are bonus points that are added to a Passed Result after the student achieves a Passing Score. The Attempt Condition describes which attempts could receive the mod, either as a range of values (written similarly to the range of scores in Score Actions), a single value, or as the variable $last_attempt. The reward describes how many points to add to the Passed Result, with positive numbers increasing the score (up to a maximum of 100) and negative number decreasing the score.

In this assessment, the Rubric lists a 75% as the Passing Score and sets the Passed Result and Failed Result so that students who make at least 75% will receive a 100%, but students who do not make at least 75% will receive a 0%. Students who take all three attempts and never make at least a 75% will receive a score of 50%. There are also mods that show all of the possible options for ranges and rewards.
